Putin at a meeting in Slovakia in 2005, will have been finished two years ahead of schedule. </s> <s> @-@ It includes measures that have long been part of American efforts to ensure that none of Russia @-@ s nuclear weapons or materials, poorly secured after the Soviet Union collapsed, fall out of government control. </s> <s> They include alarm and motion-detection systems, modern gates, guardhouses and fighting positions, as well as detectors for explosives, radiation and metal. </s> <s> @-@ The program @-@ s completion ahead of schedule appeared to have political as well as security significance at a time when relations between the countries have been strained. </s> <s> Two American nonproliferation officials said the new round of nuclear security upgrades shows that even in times of renewed tension between Washington and the Kremlin, American teams have been working closely with Russian officials at some of the country @-@ s most classified sites. </s> <s> In a telephone interview, William H. <unk>, a senior nonproliferation official at the National Nuclear Security Administration, said the program had reduced the chance of unauthorized access at the nuclear weapon sites and that it was @-@ continued evidence of this bright spot in U. RohatynNEW YORK @-@ The shift of large amounts of capital to developing countries over the past two decades has posed a major challenge to old ideas about foreign control of important national companies. </s> <s> China and Abu Dhabi tested America @-@ s tolerance for foreign control over some industries deemed <unk>limits by the U. S. Congress - oil and ports - and came away badly bruised. </s> <s> In France, the mere rumor of a bid by <unk> for the yogurt maker Danone ran into emotional public opposition all the way up to the prime minister. </s> <s> In Germany and Britain, potential investments by Russia @-@ s Gazprom in the energy grids were actively discouraged. </s> <s> Yet all the while foreign exchange reserves continue to be accumulated by developing countries, especially those exporting oil. </s> <s> With the exception of Norway, all of the countries with large surpluses are developing countries. </s> <s> Sooner or later, they are bound to try to diversify their holdings; in some cases their need will be for domestic investments, such as new infrastructure, but much of the time it will be for more diversified foreign investments in lieu of the steadily weaker dollar and its low returns. </s> <s> At present, between @-@ 2 and @-@ 3 trillion are reported to have been accumulated by emerging countries in sovereign funds. </s> <s> China will start a @-@ 200 billion fund in the near future, as will Russia. </s> <s> The Arab Emirates, with @-@ 875 billion; Kuwait with @-@ 250 billion, and Saudi Arabia with @-@ 300 billion have all been active recently with investments in the London Stock Exchange and in NASDAQ in the United States, as well as <unk> @-@ s Bank in the United Kingdom and the U. S. port management company of Dubai. </s> <s> Some estimates suggest that @-@ 10- @-@ 12 trillion will have accumulated in such funds by 2016. </s> <s> How these funds will be invested and what their influence will be is one of the major questions to be resolved over the next few years. </s> <s> While this is happening, U. S. savings pools will be running down as the aging American population collects its benefits. </s> <s> As opposed to our own savings vehicles, these foreign funds will be under the political control of their governments, so their investment policies can have a major social and economic impact in America and Europe. </s> <s> This is a subject which the U. S. Treasury, as well as its counterparts in the Group of 7 major industrialized countries, have begun to review. </s> <s> Ideally, these funds would act like domestic savings institutions, with a standard structure for corporate governance, and would abstain from attempts to exercise corporate control. </s> <s> That is the policy of Norway, and that has been the policy of some of the Arab funds, such as Kuwait @-@ s and Saudi Arabia @-@ s. However, rapid accumulations are taking place in funds controlled by China and Russia, while Venezuela @-@ s Hugo Ch @-@ vez is attempting to create a mini-OPEC of his own with a few countries whose objectives may be less benign than Norway @-@ s or Kuwait @-@ s. If over the next decade foreign funds aggregate @-@ <unk> trillion, which would approximate the market value of all shares on the NYSE today, they could well prompt strong protectionist political pressures whose objective would be to balance national interests with those of the foreign investors. </s> <s> Today, the U. S. government can block foreign ownership of companies that are doing strategic defense work or are owners of assets deemed strategically important. </s> <s> However, other than congressional action, there is little to prevent most foreign buyers from acquiring 20-30 percent of important U. S. companies listed on U. S. exchanges. </s> <s> From there to 50 percent would only require the support of a few large hedge funds or private equity firms, and would result in absolute control. </s> <s> Even though foreign investment is usually seen as positive, not all foreign investment is necessarily benign. </s> <s> Ch @-@ vez is not the prime minister of Norway; Vladimir Putin is not King <unk>. </s> <s> These differences become obvious when investment includes control. </s> <s> The nationality of capital is a factor that will be increasingly taken into account, and its objectives should be clearly disclosed. </s> <s> If those objectives include control, a board such as the U. S. Treasury Department @-@ s Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States should have the right to disapprove if it concludes that the investment is not in the U. S. national interest. </s> <s> Free movements of capital are vital to Western economies. </s> <s> But we should note that open capital markets in the face of disproportionate foreign inflows may require some balancing mechanisms. </s> <s> These would probably be viewed as protectionism, and sharply criticized. </s> <s> But that may be the price we have to pay for our years of huge trade and budget deficits and a constantly weaker dollar. </s> <s> It is hard to believe that the U. S. Congress would not differentiate between a Norwegian fund and a Venezuelan, Russian or Chinese fund. </s> <s> When potential <unk>scale shifts in control are a possibility, capital will be judged not only by its quality but also by its nationality. </s> <s> That may not be a desirable outcome, but it is what politics most likely to dictate. </s> <s> And the issue is certain to become ever more acute as imbalances increase. </s> <s> It is important to start thinking now about how we will deal with it. </s> <s> Felix G. KramerBUKHARA, Uzbekistan @-@ In the <unk> brush desert south of this ancient Silk Road town, the natural gas wellheads are built on modest concrete platforms about the size of basketball courts. </s> <s> Because the gas is naturally <unk>, pumps are not needed to bring it to the surface. </s> <s> Pipes simply kiss the ground and gas pours through them. </s> <s> The issue is where the gas goes from there. </s> <s> After the breakup of the Soviet Union, the United States and Western Europe sought to ensure that Central Asia @-@ s enormous oil and gas wealth would flow through pipelines bypassing Russia. </s> <s> It was the latest version of the Great Game, the 19th-century contest between Imperial Britain and Czarist Russia for dominance in this region. </s> <s> And as a torch-lighting ceremony deep in the Uzbek desert recently made clear, so far the West is losing. </s> <s> Executives from Lukoil, the Russian oil company, and government officials from Moscow had come to inaugurate Khauzak, the latest Central Asia natural gas field to come online. </s> <s> <unk> by Lukoil, the field is estimated to hold 400 billion cubic meters, or 14 trillion cubic feet, of natural gas, which Lukoil has sold in advance for the next 32 years to Gazprom, the Russian natural gas giant. </s> <s> Coming as some political developments in the region had renewed Western companies @-@ hopes of Game. </s> <s> @-@ We have a good head start, and we will use it, @-@ said Sergei Ivanov, first deputy prime minister of Russia. </s> <s> The Bush administration - along with much of Europe - has are also trying to pry open Central Asia to Western oil investment. </s> <s> Russia is countering by stepping up its own investment in Central Asian fields and pipelines. </s> <s> Much is at stake. </s> <s> Russia is the world @-@ s largest natural gas producer and a major supplier to Europe. </s> <s> It relies on Central Asian supplies to meet these commitments. </s> <s> @-@ The Russians are very keen to fight their corner in Central Asia, @-@ said Jonathan Stern, a natural gas specialist at the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies. </s> <s> @-@ The Russians are not just cozying up @-@ to Central Asia @-@ s autocratic leaders to achieve their aims, Stern said. </s> <s> @-@ Russian companies have put their money where their mouth is. </s> <s> @-@ <unk> with cash from their own oil boom, </s> <s> After an investment of @-@ 3.5 billion, the Lukoil project will tie together three natural gas and gas condensate fields by 2011 to produce 11 billion cubic meters of natural gas a year for export. </s> <s> In the three years since Lukoil signed the production-sharing agreement with the Uzbek government for Khauzak, Uzbek politics have taken a sharp turn in Russia @-@ s favor, shutting </s> <s> In neighboring Turkmenistan, Putin secured an agreement in May to expand exports of natural gas via a branch of the Central Asia-Center natural gas pipeline, which runs along the eastern <s> @-@ Diplomatic MemoBy Thom Shanker and Mark LandlerWASHINGTON, April 27 @-@ When the United States first asked Poland and the Czech Republic to base missile defenses on their soil, the proposed interceptors and radar were cast as a prudent hedge against Iran and a guarantee that Europe @-@ s security was indivisible from that of America, which was moving ahead with defenses for its own territory. </s> <s> But with Russia @-@ s rejection of a new American invitation to cooperate on missile defense @-@ a rebuff delivered with an exclamation point when the Kremlin threatened Thursday to pull out of a treaty on conventional weapons in Europe @-@ the initiative risked driving Moscow further from Europe and dividing Europe @-@ s public over the future of its shared security. </s> <s> The caustic exchanges between Washington and Moscow, which many Europeans fear will knock the lid off the ash bin of cold war history, were the latest example of how the United States and Russia say they want to work together but talk past each other. </s> <s> The United States says the missile defenses are all about Iran, which American intelligence agencies have said is developing missiles capable of reaching Europe as well as trying to gain the means of producing nuclear weapons. </s> <s> Moscow says that they are all about Moscow, that any Iranian threat is years away and that the bases really would serve as a Trojan horse to neutralize the Kremlin @-@ s strategic rocket forces. </s> <s> The United States says that its invitation to share missile defense technology and operate radar sites together would allow Russia to enter a more mature partnership with the United States and NATO, and that all sides would win. </s> <s> Russia responds that its every act of post-cold war conciliation has only left it more tightly encircled by NATO. </s> <s> Even before negotiations begin in earnest, both sides are staking out hard positions. </s> <s> The United States says Russia will have no veto over American missile defense bases in Central Europe. </s> <s> In response, Russia has said that the new offer has done nothing to alter its opposition, and that it is prepared to kick the legs out from under other arms control agreements to show its anger. </s> <s> To be sure, this missile defense drama is only in its opening scene. </s> <s> The two missile defense sites, expected to cost about @-@ 3.5 billion, are still years away. </s> <s> At some level, the debate over the missile defense system is not even about interceptors and radar installations. </s> <s> Their effectiveness is a matter of conjecture. </s> <s> It is about Russia @-@ s perception of, and insecurity about, its role in <unk>facing Europe. </s> <s> Thus, Washington and Moscow are playing to the populations of Poland and the Czech Republic, whose Parliaments would have to approve the bases, and beyond, to a broader and quite ambivalent European public. </s> <s> If the United States hoped that the tough talk this week from Moscow would unify Europe to rally publicly behind its plans to install 10 missile interceptors in Poland and a tracking radar in the Czech Republic, it is likely to be CohenNone of the U. S. presidential candidates has seriously addressed, or seems fully aware of, what should be America @-@ s greatest foreign-policy concern - Russia @-@ s unique capacity to endanger or enhance U. S. national security. </s> <s> Despite its diminished status following the Soviet breakup in 1991, Russia alone possesses weapons that can destroy the United States, a military complex nearly America @-@ s equal in exporting arms, vast quantities of questionably secured nuclear materials sought by terrorists, and the planet @-@ s largest oil and natural gas reserves. </s> <s> It also remains the world @-@ s largest territorial country, pivotally situated in the West and the East, at the crossroads of colliding civilizations, with strategic capabilities from Europe, Iran and other Middle East nations to North Korea, China, India, Afghanistan and even Latin America. </s> <s> All things considered, U. S. and NATO military power is increasingly ensconced. </s> <s> Second, lethal dangers inherent in Moscow @-@ s impaired controls over its vast stockpiles of materials of mass destruction and thousands of missiles on hair-trigger alert, a legacy of the state @-@ s disintegration in the 1990s, exceed any such threats in the past. </s> <s> And third, also unlike before, there is no effective opposition to hawkish policies in Washington or Moscow - only influential proponents and cheerleaders. </s> <s> How did it come to this? </s> <s> Less than 20 years ago, the Soviet and American leaders, Mikhail Gorbachev and George H. W. Bush, completing a process begun by Gorbachev and President Ronald Reagan, agreed to end the Cold War @-@ with no winners and no losers @-@ and to open a new era of @-@ genuine cooperation. </s> <s> @-@ In the U. S. international interests. </s> <s> It meant Washington could break strategic promises to Russia, as when the Clinton administration began NATO @-@ s eastward expansion, and disregard extraordinary Kremlin overtures, as when the Bush administration unilaterally withdrew from the ABM Treaty and moved NATO even closer to Russia despite Putin @-@ s crucial assistance to the U. S. war effort in Afghanistan after Sept. 11. </s> <s> It even meant America was entitled to Russia @-@ s traditional sphere of security and energy supplies, from the Baltics, Ukraine and Georgia to Central Asia and the Caspian. </s> <s> Such U. S. behavior was bound to produce a Russian backlash. </s> <s> It came under Putin, but it would have been the reaction of any strong Kremlin leader, regardless of world oil prices. </s> <s> And it can no longer be otherwise. </s> <s> Those U. S. policies, now widely viewed in Moscow as an @-@ encirclement @-@ designed to keep Russia weak and control its resources, have helped revive an assertive Russian nationalism, destroy the once strong pro-American lobby and inspire widespread charges that concessions to Washington are @-@ appeasement, @-@ even @-@ capitulationism. </s> <s> @-@ The Kremlin may have overreacted, but the cause and effect threatening a new cold war are clear. </s> <s> Because the first steps in this direction were taken in Washington, so must be the initiatives to reverse it. </s> <s> Three are essential and urgent: a diplomacy that treats Russia as a sovereign great power with commensurate national interests; an end to NATO expansion before it reaches Ukraine, risking something worse than cold war, and a full resumption of negotiations to sharply reduce and fully secure all nuclear stockpiles and to prevent the impending arms race, which requires ending or agreeing on missile defense in Europe. </s> <s> Recent discussions with members of Moscow @-@ s policy elite suggest there may still be time. </s> <s> American presidential campaigns are supposed to discuss such vital issues, but Senators John McCain, Hillary Clinton and Barrack Obama have not done so. </s> <s> Instead, each has pledged to be less @-@ soft @-@ on the Kremlin, to continue the encirclement of Russia and the hectoring @-@ democracy promotion @-@ policy, both of which have only undermined U. CohenNeither of the two major American presidential candidates has seriously addressed, or even seems fully aware of, what should be our greatest foreign policy concern - Russia @-@ s singular capacity to endanger or enhance our national security. </s> <s> Despite its diminished status following the Soviet breakup in 1991, Russia alone possesses weapons that can destroy the United States, a <unk>industrial complex nearly America @-@ s equal in exporting arms, vast quantities of questionably secured nuclear materials sought by terrorists, and the planet @-@ s largest oil and natural gas reserves. </s> <s> It also remains the world @-@ s largest territorial country, pivotally situated in the West and the East, at the crossroads of colliding civilizations, with strategic capabilities from Europe, Iran and other Middle East nations to North Korea, China, India, Afghanistan and even Latin America. </s> <s> All things considered, our national security may depend more on Russia than Russia @-@ s does on us. </s> <s> And yet U. S<unk>Russian relations are worse today than they have been in 20 years. </s> <s> The relationship includes almost as many serious conflicts as it did during the cold war - among them, Kosovo, Iran, the former Soviet republics of Ukraine and Georgia, Venezuela, NATO expansion, missile defense, access to oil and the Kremlin @-@ s internal politics - and less actual cooperation, particularly in essential matters involving nuclear weapons. </s> <s> Even the current cold peace could be more dangerous than its predecessor, for three reasons: First, its front line is not in Berlin or the Third World but on Russia @-@ s own borders, where U. S. and NATO military power is increasingly ensconced. </s> <s> Second, lethal dangers inherent in Moscow @-@ s impaired controls over its vast stockpiles of materials of mass destruction and thousands of missiles on hair-trigger alert, a legacy of the state @-@ s disintegration in the 1990s, exceed any such threats in the past. </s> <s> And third, also unlike before, there is no effective domestic opposition to hawkish policies in Washington or Moscow, only influential proponents and cheerleaders. </s> <s> How did it come to this?In the U. S. policy elite and media, the nearly unanimous answer is that Russian President Vladimir Putin @-@ s antidemocratic domestic policies and @-@ <unk>imperialism @-@ destroyed that historic opportunity. </s> <s> You don @-@ t have to be a Putin apologist to understand that this is not an adequate explanation. </s> <s> During the last eight years, Putin @-@ s foreign policies have been largely a reaction to Washington @-@ s <unk>all approach to Moscow since the early 1990s, which resulted from a revised U. S. view of how the cold war ended. </s> <s> In that new <unk> narrative, America @-@ won @-@ the <unk>year conflict and post<unk> Russia was a defeated nation analogous to post-World War II Germany and Japan - a nation without full sovereignty at home or autonomous national interests abroad. </s> <s> The policy implication of that bipartisan triumphalism, which persists today, has been clear, certainly to Moscow. </s> <s> It meant that the United States had the right to oversee Russia @-@ s post<unk> political and economic development, as it tried to do directly in the 1990s, while demanding that Moscow yield to U. S. international interests. </s> <s> It meant Washington could break strategic promises to Moscow, as when the Clinton administration began NATO @-@ s eastward expansion, and disregard extraordinary Kremlin overtures, as when the Bush Administration unilaterally withdrew from the ABM treaty and granted NATO membership to countries even closer to Russia - despite Putin @-@ s crucial assistance to the U. S. war effort in Afghanistan after 9 @-@ 11. </s> <s> It even meant America was entitled to Russia @-@ s traditional sphere of security and energy supplies, from the Baltics, Ukraine and Georgia to Central Asia and the Caspian. </s> <s> Such U. S. behavior was bound to produce a Russian backlash. </s> <s> It came under Putin, but it would have been the reaction of any strong Kremlin leader. </s> <s> Those U. S. policies - widely viewed in Moscow as an @-@ encirclement @-@ designed to keep Russia weak and to control its resources - have helped revive an assertive Russian nationalism, destroy the once strong pro-American lobby, and inspire widespread charges that concessions to Washington are @-@ appeasement, @-@ even @-@ capitulationism. </s> <s> @-@ The Kremlin may have overreacted, but the cause and effect threatening a new cold war are clear. </s> <s> Because the first steps in this direction were taken in Washington, so must be initiatives to reverse it. </s> <s> Three are essential and urgent: a U. S. plans for a missile defense system in Europe. </s> <s> American presidential campaigns are supposed to discuss such vital issues, but neither John McCain nor Barack Obama has done so. </s> <s> Instead, in varying degrees, both have promised to be @-@ tougher @-@ on the Kremlin than George W. new president is assuming office in the midst of a widespread crisis of confidence in America @-@ s capacity to exercise effective leadership in world affairs. </s> <s> That may be a stark thought, but it is a fact. </s> <s> Though U. S. leadership has been essential to global stability and development, the cumulative effects of national self indulgence, financial irresponsibility, an unnecessary war and ethical transgressions have discredited that leadership. </s> <s> Making matters worse is the global economic crisis. </s> <s> The resulting challenge is compounded by issues such as climate, health and social inequality - issues that are becoming more contentious because they have surfaced in the context of what I call @-@ the global political awakening. </s> <s> @-@ For the first time in history almost all of humanity is politically activated, politically conscious and politically interactive. </s> <s> Global activism is generating a surge in the quest for cultural respect and economic opportunity in a world scarred by memories of colonial or imperial domination. </s> <s> This pertains to yet another fundamental change: The <unk>year global domination by the Atlantic powers is coming to an end, with the new pre-eminence of China and Japan. </s> <s> Waiting in the wings are India and perhaps a recovered Russia, though the latter is very insecure about its place in the world. </s> <s> In this dynamically changing world, the crisis of American leadership could become the crisis of global stability. </s> <s> Yet in the foreseeable future no state or combination of states can replace the linchpin role America plays in the international system. </s> <s> Without a U. S. recovery, there will be no global recovery. </s> <s> The only alternative to a constructive American role is global chaos. </s> <s> It follows that the monumental task facing the new president is to regain U. S. global legitimacy by <unk> a collective effort for a more inclusive system of global management. </s> <s> Four strategically pregnant words define the essence of the needed response: unify, enlarge, engage and pacify. </s> <s> To unify pertains to the effort to re-establish a shared sense of purpose between America and Europe. </s> <s> To that end, informal but frequent top-level consultations are badly needed, even though we are all aware that there that there is no such thing yet as a politically unified Europe. </s> <s> The only practical solution is to cultivate a more deliberate dialogue among the United States and the three European countries that have a global orientation: Britain, France and Germany. </s> <s> For many years, Europeans have complained they are excluded from decision<unk>, yet they are perfectly willing to let the United States assume the burdens of implementation. </s> <s> Differences over Afghanistan are but the latest example of that dilemma. </s> <s> It is to be hoped that the new U. S. president will make a deliberate effort to revitalize the U. S<unk>European dialogue. </s> <s> To enlarge entails a deliberate effort to nurture a wider coalition committed to the principle of interdependence and prepared to play a significant role in promoting more effective global management. </s> <s> It is evident, for example, that the G-8 has outlived its function. </s> <s> Accordingly, some formula for regular consultations ranging in composition from G-14 to G-16 should be devised to bring together countries with geopolitical significance as well as economic weight. </s> <s> To engage means the cultivation of top officials through informal talks among key powers, specifically the U. S., the European Triad, China, Japan, Russia and possibly India. </s> <s> A regular personal dialogue, for example, between the U. S. president and the Chinese leader would be especially beneficial to the development of a shared sense of responsibility between the only superpower and the most likely next global power. </s> <s> Without China, many of the problems we face collectively cannot be laid to rest. </s> <s> Admittedly, China is economically nationalist, but it is also a fundamentally cautious power. </s> <s> It was Deng Xiaoping who best articulated how China defines its international approach: @-@ <unk> calmly; secure our position; cope with affairs calmly; hide our capacities and <unk> our time; be good at maintaining a low profile; and never claim leadership. </s> <s> @-@ This underlines a significant distinction with Russia. </s> <s> Like Beijing, Moscow wishes to revise international patterns, but it tends to be impatient, frustrated and sometimes even threatening. </s> <s> Nonetheless, it is in the interest of the United States and of Europe to engage Russia. </s> <s> In so doing, America should seek agreements that enhance global stability, promote nuclear weapons reduction and deal with such regional problems as Iran. </s> <s> America and Europe will have to find a way of reaffirming their commitment to the integrity of Ukraine and Georgia while conveying to Russia that their interest in these two states relates to the gradual construction of a larger democratic Europe and is not designed to threaten Russia itself. </s> <s> To pacify requires a deliberate U. S. effort to avoid becoming bogged down in the vast area ranging from Suez to India. </s> <s> Urgent decisions need to be made, with Europe @-@ s help, on several potentially interactive issues. </s> <s> The <unk>Palestinian peace process needs to be a priority. </s> <s> The new president should state on the record that a peaceful accommodation between the two parties must: first, involve a demilitarized Palestinian state, perhaps with a NATO presence to enhance Israel @-@ s sense of security; second, the territorial settlement has to be based on the 1967 lines with equitable exchanges permitting Israel to incorporate the more heavily urbanized settlements on the fringes of the @-@ 67 lines; third, both parties have to accept the fact that Palestinian refugees cannot return to what is now Israel, though they should be provided with some compensation and assistance for settling preferably in the independent Palestinian state; and last, the Israelis will have to accept the fact that a durable peace will require the genuine sharing of Jerusalem as the capital of two states. </s> <s> The United States will also have to undertake seriously reciprocal negotiations with Iran. </s> <s> That means abandoning the current U. S. posture that Tehran make a one-sided concession as a precondition to talks. </s> <s> Finally, America @-@ s strategy regarding Afghanistan and Pakistan needs a basic reassessment. </s> <s> The emphasis should be shifted from military engagement to a more subtle effort to seek a decentralized political accommodation with those portions of the Taliban who are prepared to negotiate. </s> <s> A mutual accommodation should involve Taliban willingness to eliminate any Al Qaeda presence in return for Western military disengagement from the pertinent territory. </s> <s> The process should be accompanied by intensified reconstruction. </s> <s> Let me conclude on a parochial note: Unfortunately, the American public is woefully <unk> about the wider world. </s> <s> Barack Obama will have to strive to make Americans understand the novel dimensions of global realities. </s> <s> Without sounding overly partisan, I believe that he has unique intellectual and rhetorical gifts for doing just that. </s> <s> So let me end my remarks by asserting simply, @-@ Yes, we can. </s> <s> @-@ Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Jimmy Carter @-@ s national security adviser, is trustee and <unk> at the Center for Strategic and International Studies @-@ <unk> @-@ . </s> <s> This article is based on his 2008 John Whitehead lecture at <unk> House, London. </s> <s> The complete text will be published in the January issue of International Affairs @-@ London @-@ . </s> <s> By Anne BarnardMOSCOW @-@ President Hugo Ch @-@ vez of Venezuela and President Dmitri Medvedev of Russia said Tuesday that their countries would more closely coordinate their actions on global oil and gas markets and that they would work together on foreign policy, a sphere in which both countries have sought to counter U. KissingerConventional wisdom treated Dmitry Medvedev @-@ s inauguration as president of the Russian Federation as a continuation of President Vladimir Putin @-@ s two terms of Kremlin dominance and assertive foreign policy. </s> <s> A visit to Moscow with an opportunity to meet leading personalities of the political world, as well as representatives of various age groups in business and intellectual circles, convinced me that this judgment is oversimplified and premature. </s> <s> For one thing, the emerging power structure in Moscow seems more complex than conventional wisdom holds. </s> <s> It was always doubtful why, if his primary objective was to retain power, Putin, at the height of a popularity that would have allowed him to amend the Constitution to extend his term, would choose the complicated and uncertain route of becoming prime minister. </s> <s> My impression is that a new phase of Russian politics is under way. </s> <s> The statement that the president designs foreign and security policy, and the prime minister implements parts of it, has become the mantra of Russian officials from Medvedev and Putin down. </s> <s> I encountered no Russian in or out of government who doubted that some kind of redistribution of power is taking place, although they were uncertain of its outcome. </s> <s> Putin remains powerful and highly influential. </s> <s> It is likely that he has assigned to himself a watching brief over the performance of his successor; it is possible that he is keeping open the option of becoming a candidate in a future presidential election. </s> <s> Whatever the ultimate outcome, the presidential election marked a transition from a phase of consolidation to a period of modernization. </s> <s> The growing complexity of the Russian economy has generated the need for predictable legal procedures, as already foreshadowed by Medvedev. </s> <s> The operation of the Russian government with two centers of power - at least initially - may, in retrospect, appear as the beginning of an evolution toward a form of checks and balances lacking heretofore. </s> <s> What are the implications for American foreign policy?During the next several months, Russia will be concerned with working out the practical means of the distinction between design and implementation of national security policy. </s> <s> The Bush administration and the presidential campaigns would be wise to give Russia some space to work out these arrangements by restraining public comment. </s> <s> With respect to the long term, ever since the demise of the Soviet Union in 1991, a succession of American administrations has acted as if the creation of Russian democracy were a principal American task. </s> <s> Speeches denouncing Russian shortcomings and gestures drawn from the Cold War struggle for pre-eminence have occurred frequently. </s> <s> The policy of assertive intrusion into what Russians consider their own sense of self runs the risk of thwarting both geopolitical as well as moral goals. </s> <s> There are undoubtedly groups and individuals in Russia who look to America for accelerating a democratic evolution. </s> <s> But almost all observers agree that the vast majority of Russians consider America as presumptuous and determined to stunt Russia @-@ s recovery. </s> <s> Such an environment is more likely to encourage a nationalist and confrontational response than a democratic evolution. </s> <s> It would be a pity if this mood persisted because, in many ways, we are witnessing one of the most promising periods in Russian history. </s> <s> <unk> to modern open societies and engagement with them is more prolonged and intense than in any previous period of Russian history - even in the face of unfortunate repressive measures. </s> <s> We can affect it more by patience and historical understanding than by offended disengagement and public exhortations. </s> <s> This is all the more important because geopolitical realities provide an unusual opportunity for strategic cooperation between the erstwhile Cold War adversaries. </s> <s> Between them, the U. S. and Russia control 90 percent of the world @-@ s nuclear weapons. </s> <s> Russia contains the largest landmass of any country, abutting Europe, Asia and the Middle East. </s> <s> Progress toward stability, with respect to nuclear weapons, in the Middle East and in Iran, requires - or is greatly facilitated by - <unk>American cooperation. </s> <s> Confrontational rhetoric notwithstanding, Russia @-@ s leaders are conscious of their strategic limitations. </s> <s> Indeed, I would characterize Russian policy under Putin as driven in a quest for a reliable strategic partner, with America being the preferred choice. </s> <s> Russian turbulent rhetoric in recent years reflects, in part, frustration by America @-@ s seeming imperviousness to that quest. </s> <s> Two elections for the Duma and the president also have given Russian leaders an incentive to appeal to nationalist feelings rampant after a decade of perceived humiliation. </s> <s> These detours do not affect the underlying reality. </s> <s> Three issues dominate the political agenda: security; Iran; and the relation of Russia to its former dependents, especially Ukraine. </s> <s> Because of their nuclear preponderance, Russia and America have a special obligation to take the lead in global nuclear issues such as nuclear proliferation. </s> <s> Four questions need to be answered in this respect: Do Russia and the U. S. agree on the nature of the challenge posed by the acquisition of nuclear weapons by Iran? </s> <s> Do they agree on the status of the Iranian nuclear program? </s> <s> Do they agree on the diplomacy to avert the danger? </s> <s> Do they agree on what measures to take if whatever diplomacy is finally adopted fails?It is my impression that a considerable consensus is emerging between the U. S. and Russia regarding the first two questions. </s> <s> With respect to the others, both sides must keep in mind that neither is able to overcome the challenge alone or at least only with greatly increased difficulty. </s> <s> The issue of relations with Ukraine goes to the heart of both sides @-@ perceptions of the nature of international affairs. </s> <s> Genuine independence for Ukraine is essential for a peaceful international system and must be unambiguously supported by the U. S. But the movement of the Western security system from the Elbe River to the approaches to Moscow brings home Russia @-@ s decline in a way bound to generate a Russian emotion that will inhibit the solution of all other issues. </s> <s> It should be kept on the table without forcing the issue to determine the possibilities of making progress on other issues. </s> <s> The Sochi declaration of Presidents Bush and Putin in April outlined a road map for an emerging strategic dialogue between the two sides. </s> <s> It remains for the new administrations in Russia and America to give it operational context. </s> <s> Henry A. Terre Haute, IndianaBy Robert Johnston and Clifford <unk> and Robert Johnston and Clifford KupchanCommon wisdom says that Europe and Russia are bound by an umbilical cord - energy. </s> <s> EU members are dependent on Russia @-@ s oil and gas, while Russia depends on the enormous export revenues that the European market generates. </s> <s> But over the next decade, both sides have more options than commonly assumed. </s> <s> And as the Georgia conflict vividly demonstrates, for geopolitical reasons each might exercise those options. </s> <s> The current bond is tight. </s> <s> According to EU statistics, Russia in 2006 supplied 33 percent of EU oil imports and 28 percent of consumption. </s> <s> On the gas side, Russia supplied 42 percent of imports and 27 percent of consumption. </s> <s> The gas numbers have already risen, and EU dependence on imported gas is set to grow to 68 percent by <unk>. </s> <s> But the dependence is mutual, as Russian energy exports account for over 60 percent of Moscow @-@ s export revenues. </s> <s> Most observers argue that neither side has viable alternatives. </s> <s> That @-@ s true for the next few years. </s> <s> But if <unk>EU relations decay and the Europeans develop more political will, both sides have alternatives over the medium term - 5 to 10 years - that could limit their energy relationship. </s> <s> Europe could take a number of steps, in many cases by accelerating programs that are already well underway. </s> <s> In isolation, each step would make a marginal difference, but in the aggregate and in the <unk> the EU could reduce its <unk> dependence on Moscow. </s> <s> On the gas side, the EU already has increased supply from Norway at the expense of Russia. </s> <s> In 2000, Russia supplied 49 percent of EU imports, while Norway stood at 21 percent. </s> <s> By 2006, Russia dropped to 42 percent while Norway grew to 24 percent. </s> <s> And Norway has the reserves to provide increasing volumes to the EU. </s> <s> Europe is also turning to North Africa for gas. </s> <s> Two pipelines from Algeria and one from Libya provide supply, with plans for another line @-@ Algeria-Italy @-@ moving forward. </s> <s> Libya is the wild card here, as the size of its reserves is uncertain. </s> <s> Liquified Natural Gas is a significant but expensive alternative for the EU. </s> <s> Europe would have to build significantly more regasification terminals, and then would have to outbid Northeast Asian customers for supply. </s> <s> It @-@ s also a risky option, as many LNG suppliers carry their own political risk - Egypt, Nigeria and Yemen are good examples. </s> <s> Yet the EU countries already had 14 operational LNG regasification terminals at the end of 2007, with 14 more under construction. </s> <s> The electricity sector is a key area for EU diversification because natural gas consumption for producing electricity offers a wide range of substitutes. </s> <s> This sector accounts for 31 percent of EU natural gas consumption and natural gas-fired power plants produced 20 percent of EU electricity in 2006. </s> <s> Increased energy efficiency, wind and solar power, and <unk> energy could all displace gas power plants. </s> <s> Nuclear power and clean coal @-@ which remains prospective technology @-@ will also play a role in displacing natural gas, especially in markets such as Britain, Eastern Europe and Italy. </s> <s> A significant EU-wide shift would require a change in some nations on the acceptability of nuclear plants, particularly Germany and Spain, and those facilities have a 5-to-7 year lead time. </s> <s> On the oil side, the EU could more easily diversify, given the global and highly fungible nature of the oil market. </s> <s> Russian pipelines and ports were built to efficiently serve Europe; disruption of Moscow @-@ s oil exports would cause short-term dislocations that could last weeks and cause global market upheaval as EU importers scramble for seaborne alternatives from other suppliers. </s> <s> But the EU would obtain alternative volumes of oil, if at much higher price. </s> <s> Russia too has other options for diversifying its export markets - if geopolitical developments drives Moscow to exercise them. </s> <s> A promising diversification strategy would involve Beijing, should Russia finally elect to implement its <unk> plans and build large new gas pipelines to China with perhaps a 5-year lead time. </s> <s> Using the new China routes, Russia could divert volumes from Europe and supply China without much additional production. </s> <s> This scenario would likely be expensive for Russia, given the massive costs of infrastructure development. </s> <s> On the positive side, China is showing greater willingness to pay higher prices for LNG, which indicates increasing demand for imported gas and could lead to an agreement with Moscow on price for Russian pipeline gas. </s> <s> On oil, the new East Siberia Pacific Ocean pipeline will likely help bring 600,000 barrels per day to Asian markets by 2010, and by late in the next decade Phase II of the project could bring an additional 1 million barrels per day to Asian consumers. </s> <s> Moscow hopes to find most of this volume in the forbidding climate of East Siberia, and not serve Asia at the expense of Europe. </s> <s> But Russia is politically committed to this line, and if tensions increase it could be an attractive outlet for existing volumes. </s> <s> These oil and gas options are not yet as economically attractive for Russia as European markets, but they are options. </s> <s> What then could motivate the Russians and Europeans to seek an expensive divorce? </s> <s> Several political flash points could drive the EU and Russia apart. </s> <s> First, Russia will need @-@ s decision to host U. S. missile defense installations. </s> <s> That would set off alarm bells. </s> <s> Third, Russia defines energy security as security of demand for its producers - meaning acquisition of downstream assets in the European Union. </s> <s> The strategy has worked well with Germany and Italy; for example, BASF and ENI have received access to the Russian upstream in return for Gazprom obtaining access in Europe @-@ s downstream. </s> <s> But this model has worked less well with Britain and other countries. </s> <s> In the aftermath of Georgia, stiffer governmental reviews of prospective Russian investment are more likely in the United States - and possibly the European Union. </s> <s> That could well trigger a backlash from Moscow and <unk> its energy relations with Europe. </s> <s> Finally, the U. PetroKINGSTON, Rhode Island @-@ Like the heroes in Leo Tolstoy @-@ s short story, Russia and America have become @-@ Prisoners in the Caucasus, @-@ their options constrained by the irreconcilable positions of <unk> whose hostilities dates back centuries. </s> <s> But while Russians have more than two centuries of historical, political, cultural and military experience to guide them in this crisis, the Bush administration is a novice to the region. </s> <s> It shows. </s> <s> The administration @-@ s main argument for supporting Georgian sovereignty seems to be that Georgia has a rare combination of two virtues: 1 @-@ a staunchly pro-American strongman, Mikheil <unk>, whose lapses into martial law and seizure of opposition television stations are quickly forgiven; and 2 @-@ the Baku-Tbilisi-<unk> @-@ BTC @-@ pipeline, which connects the Caspian oilfields to the Black Sea. </s> <s> Over the past four years, this combination has led to an investment of American prestige and money in Georgia that is wildly out of proportion to any possible benefit for the United States. </s> <s> One reason is that neither the BTC, nor its much heralded <unk> partner, Nabucco, can ever hope to make a serious dent in Europe @-@ s thirst for energy. </s> <s> That is why, well before the current crisis, major investors and governments in the region have been quietly switching their support from Nabucco to Russia @-@ s own pipeline expansion project - Southstream. </s> <s> These economic realities have not changed. </s> <s> Another dangerous sign is the exaggerated rhetoric of American officials, which reveals a clear lack of understanding that the current crisis, far from being unique, is only the latest in a very long series of ethnic confrontations in the Caucasus. </s> <s> Coupled with the ignorance of the Western mass media about the Caucasus and the political ambitions of Senator John McCain, for whom Russia-bashing is a convenient way to establish his foreign policy credentials, it is not surprising that the narrative that has emerged is @-@ Russia invades Georgia. </s> <s> @-@ The danger of this simplistic and misleading narrative is that it prevents Americans from recognizing the danger that accompanies an open-ended U. S. commitment to Georgia - namely the extent to which American foreign policy is held hostage to the ambitions of actors in the region, thus transforming America, along with Russia, into a prisoner of the Caucasus. </s> <s> While U. S. and Russian leaders may not see it, they are in a similar bind. </s> <s> The only way out is for them to work together on a comprehensive settlement for the region. </s> <s> Failure to do so may or may not lead to direct confrontation with Russia, but will surely lead to America getting entangled in the passions of the Caucasus, like the Ottoman, Persian and Russian empires before it. </s> <s> However, there is a way to stabilize the situation, promote self-determination and democracy, and restore the tattered credibility of the West in the region. </s> <s> It rests on an international peacekeeping mission with a very carefully crafted mandate. </s> <s> Critical to the success of such a mission would be an explicit commitment by the West that would lead to the independence of South Ossetia and Abkhazia from Georgia if the parties fail to reach a mutually acceptable accord, as in the case of Kosovo. </s> <s> Under these conditions both South Ossetia and Abkhazia would probably accept Western peacekeepers. </s> <s> With the backing of the South Ossetian and Abkahz leadership secured, Russia would have little choice but to support the deployment of international peacekeepers. </s> <s> Over time it is possible that Russia would come to regard them as preferable to being the sole military and economic guarantor of peace in the region, a role it has been forced to play for the past 15 years. </s> <s> The one, unavoidable, downside to this proposal is that it would be termed a betrayal by <unk>, whose popularity rests on his pledge to establish sovereignty over all of Georgia. </s> <s> He is supported in this ambition by many in the Georgian political elite who remain wedded to the idea of an imperial Georgia, from the Black Sea to the Caspian. </s> <s> But giving up South Ossetia and Abkhazia, which have both demonstrated an unbending desire for independence from Georgia and have sacrificed thousands of lives to this since 1991, may be the only way to safeguard the territorial integrity of the rest of Georgia. </s> <s> It is simply inconceivable that after the latest Georgian <unk>, either of these two regions will allow Georgia to rule over them, though some form of confederation may still be remotely possible. </s> <s> And Georgia remains a <unk> of diverse nationalities, with the separatists in Abkhazia and Southern Ossetia being only the most obvious. </s> <s> Svanetia, Javakhetia and Mingrelia also have restless local and political elites. </s> <s> Sometimes, as in the case of Adjaria, they can be bought off, but in the Caucasus such arrangements are highly personal, not institutional. </s> <s> Ultimately, the only way to ensure Georgia @-@ s political stability and integrity is for the U. S., Russia and the European Union to coordinate their actions, as they did in arranging the peaceful departure from office of former president Eduard Shevardnadze. </s> <s> The imposition of @-@ Kosovo terms @-@ on all the parties in the conflict would put the Georgian political elite before a clear deadline to come up with terms that are acceptable to other ethnic constituencies, or to give up what Shevardnadze once referred to as their @-@ mini-empire. </s> <s> @-@ Since international peacekeepers will only be accepted by the Abkhaz and South Ossetians if approved by Russia, whom they see as their only true friend in the international community, such coordination would have the added benefit of establishing a dialogue on practical areas where the United States, Russia and the EU share a common objective. </s> <s> Coming to terms with a <unk> identity will be a painful process for Georgia. </s> <s> But, as for Russia and Serbia, it will ultimately lead to a more stable domestic political consensus. </s> <s> <unk> N. <unk> is professor of international politics at the University of Rhode Island. </s> <s> He served as the U. S. missile shield has become such a contentious issue between the United States and Russia - and indeed between Poland and Russia - that President Vladimir Putin of Russia has warned of a new arms race if Washington proceeds with deployment in Poland and the Czech Republic. </s> <s> Having accused Washington of threatening Russia @-@ s national security interests, Putin last month suspended his nation @-@ s participation in the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty. </s> <s> Under that treaty, one of the last major arms pacts concluded between the former Cold War foes, countries stretching from Canada across Europe to the eastern parts of Russia cut their conventional forces and agreed to on-site inspections and an elaborate system of verification and notifications. </s> <s> It was implemented in 1992. </s> <s> The Kremlin did not say how long it would suspend its participation. </s> <s> But Russian diplomats said it depended on not only what kind of concessions the United States was prepared to make concerning changes to the treaty, but also whether Poland and the Czech Republic would deploy part of the U. Marks of the Podhurst Orseck law firm, argued that a new lawsuit was valid because the bank @-@ s 2005 settlement qualified as a criminal admission of guilt, making it liable for civil damages. </s> <s> The case, being heard at Basmany Court in Moscow, has attracted the attention of prominent legal experts. </s> <s> Alan M. last year. </s> <s> By Clifford J. </s> <s> Levy and Peter <unk> @-@ President Obama signed an agreement on Monday to cut American and Russian strategic nuclear arsenals by at least one-quarter, a Letter From <unk> Celestine Bohlen @-@ Bloomberg NewsPARIS @-@ China @-@ s proposal isn @-@ t about wobbly exchange rates. </s> <s> It @-@ s about making a statement before this week @-@ s Group of 20 summit meeting. </s> <s> China, together with Russia and others, wants to let Washington know that it is going to have to share the head table in what used to be an exclusive club. </s> <s> China @-@ s ascendancy was a fact before the financial crisis. </s> <s> Now its political clout is catching up with its economic might. </s> <s> But when it comes to currency, the dollar is still king, and it will probably remain so for some time. </s> <s> Think about it. </s> <s> Who seriously expects to see commodities - from gold to cotton to oil - priced in anything but dollars anytime soon? </s> <s> There have been times when Russia, Iran and Venezuela considered pricing crude in euros, but that idea evaporated for one simple reason: Depreciating the dollar ends up harming those countries that hold them in reserve. </s> <s> The first victim would be China, now the largest holder of U. S. Treasury securities - about @-@ 740 billion worth, more than a third of its entire foreign reserves. </s> <s> The truth is you can @-@ t dictate which reserve currency countries will use, any more than you can make people speak Esperanto, a universal language invented 112 years ago that still hasn @-@ t taken off. </s> <s> The euro is a common currency that did take off, although its track record is heavily debated. </s> <s> Frugal Germans fret about having to pay for <unk> Greeks, while countries like Italy long for the days when they could get out of trouble by <unk> their currencies. </s> <s> The euro, now shared by 16 countries, is here to stay, but so far it hasn @-@ t been copied anywhere. </s> <s> Kazakhstan is pushing for the acmetal, while China wants its <unk> to be accepted throughout Southeast Asia. </s> <s> Neither project is ready to leap into life. </s> <s> A plan by the Chinese central bank governor, Zhou Xiaochuan, posted on the bank @-@ s Web site last week, was even more ambitious. </s> <s> He wants to move to a global reserve currency with a stable valuation benchmark that belongs to no individual nation. </s> <s> If the euro zone has trouble managing 16 European nations, imagine the nightmare of managing a currency on a worldwide scale. </s> <s> So far, no one has come up with a good idea for an alternative to the dollar. </s> <s> China and Russia propose expanding the use of the International Monetary Fund @-@ s special drawing rights, or S. D. R. @-@ s, a cumbersome vehicle whose value is set by a basket of currencies. </s> <s> Russia has added the idea of putting gold in the basket as a stabilizing element. </s> <s> The I. M. F.? </s> <s> Is that really the institution we want to manage complex international monetary politics? </s> <s> Critics have already questioned how the I. M. F. would go about setting the value of the S. D. R. @-@ s and how it would resist political pressure to change the valuation. </s> <s> For its part, the United States will obviously defend the dollar @-@ s dominance as long as it can. </s> <s> Its status as the No. </s> <s> 1 currency means the United States doesn @-@ t have to repay debts in foreign tender, keeping borrowing costs down. </s> <s> A weaker dollar would make it harder to sell the Treasury securities the government needs to jump-start the economy. </s> <s> A strong dollar is in America @-@ s interest, the U. OrrTOKYO @-@ Some time in coming months, Japan will hold new elections. </s> <s> In all likelihood the result will be further deadlock domestically and continued mutual frustration over efforts to transform the U. S<unk>Japan alliance into one with truly global reach and significance. </s> <s> The old @-@ iron triangle @-@ of the Liberal Democratic Party, the bureaucracy and the business world can no longer govern effectively. </s> <s> But neither the advent of the Democratic Party of Japan nor the prospect of generational change promises anything much different. </s> <s> Yet while Japan drifts, the environment in Asia is becoming ever more challenging. </s> <s> China @-@ s economic and political clout continues to expand and its burgeoning anti-ship ballistic missile capabilities pose a particular threat to U. S. naval forces in the region. </s> <s> North Korea is forging ahead again with the development of nuclear weapons and the Putin @-@ Medvedev government appears determined to reassert Russian interests in Asia. </s> <s> Couple this with the unending discussions between the United States and Japan over the future of U. S. bases on Okinawa and there @-@ s a recipe for trouble. </s> <s> These are not new issues for the United States or Japan, but in the past they have been balanced by the capacity of the U. S. to project its economic and military power in the region. </s> <s> Of late, however, some Japanese and Americans have begun to wonder how long the United States can sustain that role. </s> <s> The strains on America are manifest: wars in Iraq, Afghanistan and Pakistan, and an economic stimulus package critically dependent upon a continued Chinese appetite for American debt. </s> <s> The Obama administration would like to see Japan as an active regional and global partner in dealing with nuclear proliferation and terrorism. </s> <s> The two nations share basic values and have increasingly integrated economies. </s> <s> Japan is also home to the bulk of the U. S. forces in Asia. </s> <s> But in view of the deepening quagmire in Japan @-@ s domestic politics, U. S. policymakers may need to scale down their ambitions for the role they wish to assign Japan. </s> <s> More than 60 years after World War II, Japan is still generally isolated in the Asian region. </s> <s> It remains heavily dependent on the United States for its defense and the health of the U. S. economy for its growth @-@ not a positive state of affairs for U. S. policymakers trying to cope with rising regional powers and economic difficulties of their own. </s> <s> Moreover, mounting voter frustration in Japan with an unresponsive political system leaves the door ajar for nationalist politicians and policies, which undermine Tokyo @-@ s ability to cooperate on pressing issues. </s> <s> What policies can the new administration in Washington pursue to update and strengthen the alliance? </s> <s> First, the U. S. should set forces in motion to @-@ multilateralize @-@ the security relationship with Japan. </s> <s> A narrowly focused contingency scenario for Korea that <unk> back 60 years is no longer adequate. </s> <s> It will be necessary to recast the alliance to support a clearer balancing role for U. S. forces, a role more closely attuned to Japanese domestic political realities and regional requirements. </s> <s> Specifically, the reduction of the U. S. Marine presence in Okinawa should be carried out in the context of a broader consolidation of all U. S. forces in Japan, with the goal of ultimately forging a more manageable and defensible posture @-@ over the horizon @-@ on Guam. </s> <s> This would remove many of the <unk> associated with the U. seemed overly technical and easily resolved, if there were the slightest desire on either side. </s> <s> After all, both countries stand to profit from selling fuel to Europe. </s> <s> The latest agreement collapsed Tuesday, in a familiar cacophony of complaints and countercomplaints - again over a seemingly trivial issue. </s> <s> With European Union monitors along the pipeline to make sure that Ukraine did not divert any gas for its own use, Russia agreed to resume shipments to Europe. </s> <s> But rather than repressuring the Ukrainian pipeline system for exports, the Russian gas monopoly, Gazprom, ordered a single test shipment to see if it would pass through Ukraine to Europe, through a pipeline that was being used to supply the Ukrainian city of Odessa. </s> <s> The Ukrainian authorities refused, saying they did not want to cut supplies to their own people, and Russia again halted shipments - not, some specialists believed, reluctantly. </s> <s> Political experts say that neither side is motivated to settle the dispute, because it has never been about the stated issues. </s> <s> Instead, it has been a proxy for far more fundamental and insoluble matters, particularly Ukraine @-@ s turn to the West in the 2004 @-@ Orange Revolution, @-@ which deeply shook Russian nationalists. </s> <s> @-@ The Russian side is appealing to a lot of technical details to interview. </s> <s> @-@ It @-@ s very clear to see the desire to pressure the Ukrainian politicians, and pressure them that if they continue to pursue a pro-Western course and not adhere to the rules Kuchins and Thomas SandersonTASHKENT, <unk> @-@ Russian agreement to allow U. S. military <unk>flight rights to ferry lethal goods to Afghanistan was one of the signal achievements of the recent meetings in Moscow between Presidents Barack Obama and Dimtri Medvedev. </s> <s> Last month in Moscow, Russian officials told us that Afghanistan was the area where American and Russian interests are most closely aligned, and cooperation on stabilizing Afghanistan may be the most promising area to @-@ reset @-@ our bilateral relationship. </s> <s> Less publicized has been Moscow @-@ s agreement earlier this year to allow for overland transit of nonlethal goods through Russian territory and on to Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan @-@ with Kazakh and Uzbek agreement, of course @-@ where they cross into northern Afghanistan at Heraton. </s> <s> These goods are shipped on trains that originate in the Latvian capital of Riga, and since the transit corridor was established, at least 20 rail convoys have made the trip. </s> <s> The supply trains have been given preferential <unk>of-way to speed the trip to about nine days. </s> <s> Perhaps even less well-known is that Russian commercial cargo carriers have been shipping <unk> goods out of the Middle East aboard massive Antonov 124 @-@ Ruslan @-@ cargo planes to Afghanistan for more than a year. </s> <s> To the great relief of the Pentagon, whose own cargo fleet is under tremendous stress, this heavy lift service was one of the few areas of U. S<unk>Russian cooperation that did not fall victim to the breakdown in the relationship last year over the Georgia war. </s> <s> It seems a little odd that aspects of this cooperation on Afghanistan @-@ one of Washington @-@ s highest foreign and security policy challenges @-@ are not better known. </s> <s> Perhaps that is because there remain questions about just how much Russia wants to see the United States succeed in Afghanistan. </s> <s> This issue was certainly raised earlier this year when the government of Kyrgyzstan announced that it would close the U. S. base in Manas, a decision that was reversed shortly before the Obama-Medvedev meeting last month, presumably with Russian support. </s> <s> In our recent discussions in Tashkent with very high-level Uzbek government officials, this question came up repeatedly, and the answers we got were not reassuring. </s> <s> Uzbekistan is the key country in the establishment of the northern supply route, what the U. S. military calls the Northern Distribution Network. </s> <s> The United States needs the NDN both because of its <unk>reliance on a single line of transit through volatile regions of Pakistan and because its growing military force in Afghanistan will require a threefold increase in supplies. </s> <s> Uzbek officials are deeply skeptical of Moscow. </s> <s> They believe the Russians see their interests best served by continued instability in Afghanistan. </s> <s> Instability will increase both the terrorist threat to Central Asia as well as the flow of drugs, and serve to justify a heightened Russian military presence in the region. </s> <s> Afghan instability also prevents opening or expanding southern transit corridors for Central Asian exports that could quickly reach global markets from ports in either Pakistan or Iran. </s> <s> Instead, the bulk of goods from Uzbekistan and its neighbors must be shipped northward, leaving them dependent on routes controlled by Moscow. </s> <s> The Russians already have a major military presence in Tajikistan, as well as an air base in Kyrgyzstan at <unk>, near the Manas airport outside the capital of <unk>. </s> <s> Moscow hopes to finalize an agreement soon to establish a new base in Kyrgyzstan near the southern city of Osh in the volatile Fergana Valley that would house a newly established Rapid Reaction Force @-@ mostly manned by Russian troops @-@ of the Collective Security Treaty Organization. </s> <s> @-@ Tashkent views the growing Russian military presence in the region as a security threat. </s> <s> The manner in which Russian @-@ peace-keeping @-@ forces were mobilized in the Georgia war last summer made a deep impact on Uzbek policymakers, heightening their sense of vulnerability. </s> <s> Uzbek skepticism about Russian goals is so deep that several key figures <unk> that when it comes to Afghanistan, Iran would be a more reliable partner for Washington than Moscow. </s> <s> The Uzbeks we spoke with were unanimous in the view that eventual success in stabilizing Afghanistan requires as much attention to social-economic development as it does to military goals. </s> <s> Any security gains will certainly be short-lived if Afghanistan remains impoverished and economically isolated. </s> <s> Building a transportation infrastructure linking Afghanistan to regional and global markets will be essential for this success and should be a key element of President Obama @-@ s regional strategy for Afghanistan. </s> <s> For strategic and economic reasons, Uzbekistan wants to be a key These successes, however, give rise to a legitimate question: What next?NATO now confronts historically unprecedented risks to global security. </s> <s> The paradox of our time is that the world, expanding mass unrest make for a combustible mixture. </s> <s> In this dangerous setting, the first order of business for NATO members is to define and pursue together a politically acceptable outcome the fact is that the qualified wording of Article 5 allows each country to do as much or as little as it thinks appropriate in response to an attack on a fellow NATO member, and NATO @-@ s reliance upon consensus for decision<unk> enables even just one or two members in effect to veto any response at all @-@ a problem made more acute by the expansion of the alliance to 28 members and the </s> <s> Russia is not an enemy, but it still views NATO with hostility. </s> <s> Hence, two strategic objectives should define NATO @-@ s goal: to consolidate security in Europe by drawing Russia LordIn salary negotiations in the business world, there @-@ s a simple axiom: The first person who mentions a number loses. </s> <s> The same is true for arms-control negotiations. </s> <s> When one side tips its hand by revealing its numerical goal, the other side has a distinct advantage. </s> <s> In that sense, the proposal of Henry Kissinger, George Schultz, William Perry and Sam Nunn for a nuclear @-@ zero option @-@ is a loser. </s> <s> But even if these four statesmen @-@ s crusade for a nuclear-free world employs questionable tactics, it can help the United States, Russia and other nuclear powers reframe the debate about their nuclear arsenals. </s> <s> In that sense, it could still turn out to be a winner. </s> <s> During the Cold War, the United States and the Soviet Union drove up their stockpiles of nuclear weapons to dizzying heights. </s> <s> The idea was to survive a nuclear first strike, and still have plenty of warheads left to strike back. </s> <s> Gradually, arms-control negotiations introduced ceilings on weapons, along with trust-building inspection and verification procedures. </s> <s> The problem with the @-@ zero option @-@ is that it fails to reflect how much the world has changed since the Cold War. </s> <s> Yes, U. </s> <s> S and Russian stockpiles still account for more than 90 percent of the estimated 27,000 nuclear warheads in the world. </s> <s> But the number of nuclear states keeps growing, and it includes such regional powers as China and India. </s> <s> Any new arms reductions must take the new players into account along with the old Cold War rivals. </s> <s> That won @-@ t happen if arms control is seen as counting down from the huge U. S. and Russian arsenals, as the @-@ zero option @-@ implies. </s> <s> A far better approach would be to count up from zero. </s> <s> In other words, the U. S. and Russia would act upon the premise that they are no longer enemies, but each has legitimate security concerns about the new rapidly evolving, increasingly complex global nuclear lineup. </s> <s> As a first step, the U. S. and Russia need to extend the inspection and verification provisions of the START Treaty, which is due to expire at the end of 2009. </s> <s> But the truly innovative part will be to pursue the goal of a new nuclear strategy that isn @-@ t driven by the current numbers of nuclear weapons each side possesses. </s> <s> Instead, it should be driven by the best estimates on what constitutes adequate deterrence levels against a broad array of new threats, including possible actions by countries like Iran and North Korea. </s> <s> To determine those deterrence levels, the United States and Russia should seek to work out joint threat assessments. </s> <s> This would involve intense <unk>to-military contacts and engagement, along with the high-level political involvement that is necessary for such an effort to achieve its aims. </s> <s> Rather than starting with the question how far current arsenals can be reduced, such an assessment would survey the current global line-up and then count up from zero. </s> <s> If they did so, both countries would almost certainly emerge with far fewer warheads than if they take the count-down-to-zero approach. </s> <s> Aside from encouraging new U. S<unk>Russia cooperation, this strategy would allow the two big nuclear powers to demonstrate to the rest of the field that they recognize their special obligation to set the tone for the broader discussion on nuclear arsenals. </s> <s> They can @-@ t expect other nuclear states, and even those who aspire to join that club, to take their appeals for nonproliferation seriously if they aren @-@ t serious themselves. </s> <s> Of course countries like China, India and Pakistan may not be all that impressed even if the U. S. and Russia determine that they can meet their defense needs with dramatically smaller arsenals. </s> <s> But if the Obama adminstration and the Medvedev-Putin team are seen as working together to alter the nuclear landscape, they will have a far better chance to reach out to others to join them. </s> <s> Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev first championed the idea of abolishing nuclear weapons in the 1980s, and the @-@ four <unk> @-@ - Kissinger, Schultz, Perry and Nunn - have performed a valuable service by reviving that seemingly utopian vision. </s> <s> This may be and perhaps even should be an unattainable goal, but it could trigger the most significant breakthrough on nuclear weapons ever. </s> <s> Retired General Lance W. and alternative minimum tax relief all expire in December 2010, and that discretionary spending increases only in line with inflation after 2010. </s> <s> The falling debt projection also assumes that <s> Finally, the projection assumes interest rates in the United States remain low. </s> <s> With Treasury bond maturities now averaging only 48 months, higher interest rates would rapidly feed into higher borrowing costs and budget deficits. </s> <s> @-@ No European government has done anything as <unk> as we have, @-@ Ferenc Gyurcsany, Hungary @-@ s prime minister, said of his country @-@ s fiscal policy in May 2006. </s> <s> By 2012, United States policy makers may be echoing his words. </s> <s> China @-@ s <unk>?China @-@ s @-@ 25 billion oil purchase agreement with Russia trades cash for bargain-priced oil over 20 years. </s> <s> That solves a chunk of China @-@ s long-term supply problem. </s> <s> Russia may be politically unreliable, but the advantages of the deal make it well worth the risk. </s> <s> In return for @-@ 25 billion in loans, China will get a total of about 2.2 billion barrels of oil over 20 years. </s> <s> Including interest at 5 percent, that equates to a price of @-@ <unk> a barrel over the period, a bargain when the longest New York <unk> Exchange futures contract, for December 2017, sells at @-@ 73.22 a barrel. </s> <s> The contract covers about 8 percent of China @-@ s current oil imports, which are expected to increase sharply in coming years. </s> <s> The Chinese authorities regard long-term oil supplies as a key matter of national security, and are not prepared to rely more than modestly on the international spot market. </s> <s> Hence in recent years, Chinese oil companies have invested in a number of African countries to line up supplies, and have had lengthy discussions with <unk>rich but unreliable Venezuela. </s> <s> Given its energy concerns, a 20-year contact with even the erratically governed Russia could be regarded as only moderately risky. </s> <s> Russian oil companies may be less likely to default on a deal with China, which takes a strong stance in most international matters, than they would be on an equivalent obligation to the more passive European Union, for example. </s> <s> Russia gets the capital needed to upgrade its oil industry and establishes a long-term relationship with a large and growing customer. </s> <s> Even the low equivalent price of this contract probably represents a profit considering Russia @-@ s low extraction costs. </s> <s> It also provides guaranteed demand in case of an oil glut. </s> <s> This looks like a good deal for both sides, but Russia @-@ s cash flow needs and the fall in oil prices seem to have given Chinese negotiators the advantage. </s> <s> <unk> HUTCHINSON Op-Ed ContributorBy Mikhail <unk> @-@ The past few years have been a very difficult period in relations between the United States and Russia. </s> <s> Problems remained unsolved and, even worse, mutual trust took a nosedive. </s> <s> As a result, both sides sometimes acted without thinking through the consequences, which were felt not just in the United States and Russia but elsewhere as well. </s> <s> The recent visit of President Barack Obama to Russia was a first step toward an exit from the deadlocked state of our relations. </s> <s> In the run-up to the visit, many American pundits asserted that relations with Russia were far from the U. S. administration @-@ s list of top priorities. </s> <s> Here in Moscow, some have gone so far as to say that a @-@ cold war is good for Russia. </s> <s> @-@ Against such a backdrop, the fact itself that the visit took place may be regarded as a success. </s> <s> It would of course be an illusion to expect major results so soon after the long years of stalled relations. </s> <s> Yet it would be a mistake to underestimate what was accomplished both at the preparatory stages and during the visit. </s> <s> These first steps are meaningful. </s> <s> @-@ They include agreement on a framework for a future legally binding treaty on reducing strategic offensive arms. </s> <s> In this context, reaffirmation of the <unk> between these weapons and missile defense was a notable achievement. </s> <s> By accepting it, the Obama administration sent an important signal. </s> <s> An agreement was reached to resume <unk>to-military contacts between Russia and the United States, which could make an important contribution to rebuilding mutual trust. </s> <s> @-@ On these issues, the United States showed signs of a more realistic attitude. </s> <s> For its part, Russia took a serious step by agreeing to the transit through its territory of U. S. combat equipment en route to Afghanistan. </s> <s> Given the amount of cargo involved, this agreement required settling a number of difficult technical and legal issues. </s> <s> The fact that they were resolved shows readiness to fight terrorism by deeds, and not just words. </s> <s> These first agreements are important. </s> <s> No less consequential were statements made by the two leaders during the visit. </s> <s> President Obama said the United States would not try to unilaterally solve priority problems, like combating violent extremism and preventing the spread of nuclear weapons. </s> <s> In his keynote speech, he said the United States wanted to work with Russia bilaterally as well as together in third countries. </s> <s> That point was noted here, for there is a great deal of lingering mutual mistrust as to the two countries @-@ intentions, particularly in what is called @-@ the post<unk> space. </s> <s> @-@ Changing such attitudes will be difficult, but a start must be made somewhere. </s> <s> @-@ As I see it, one area where the United States and Russia could engage each other in a useful dialogue is relations in Europe. </s> <s> This could help flesh out the idea, put forward by President Dmitry Medvedev, for a new pan-European security treaty. </s> <s> Indeed, the structure of security in Europe can be designed only if our two nations are among its architects. </s> <s> A serious dialogue is therefore in order. </s> <s> @-@ As part of his visit to Moscow, President Obama made a special effort to engage a broad cross-section of Russian society. </s> <s> He showed an ability to listen and sought to persuade his listeners that our two nations have shared interests and compatible values. </s> <s> I hope the president @-@ s contacts with the Russian public be. </s> <s> So now comes the hard part: consolidating the new atmosphere by following up in all areas of mutual relations. </s> <s> Success must be the work of both sides. </s> <s> It is encouraging that the two presidents will head a joint commission to guide and oversee this work. </s> <s> @-@ The new course in U. S<unk>Russian relations will meet with resistance from various quarters. </s> <s> There is also the danger that the new relationship could be mired in inertia and routine. </s> <s> The two presidents must exercise political will to prevent negotiations on important issues from <unk> into an endless <unk>war. </s> <s> The results that could be achieved if they truly invest in a new relationship are well worth the effort. </s> <s> In a world where daunting unpredictable risks are mounting on a daily basis, Russia with its natural and intellectual resources and America with its power and influence must cooperate. </s> <s> The benefits will accrue to them and to the rest of the world as well. </s> <s> The missed opportunities and mistakes of the past years are a legacy that will not be easy to shake off. </s> <s> But, as Russia and the United States set off on a new course, its promise must be given a chance. </s> <s> By Clifford J. </s> <s> Levy and Peter <unk> @-@ President Obama @-@ s decision to cancel an antimissile defense system in Eastern Europe earned a strong welcome from Russian leaders on Friday. </s> <s> Now, the question is whether Russia will do more to help prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons. </s> <s> Prime Minister Vladimir V.
