that domestic and international policy on competition and ownership issues can no longer be separated. </s> <s> Op-Ed Contributor By Zbigniew BrzezinskiIn the course of its 60 years, NATO has institutionalized three monumental transformations in world affairs: first, the end of the centuries-long @-@ civil war @-@ within the West for <unk>oceanic and European supremacy; second, the United States @-@ s post @-@ World War II commitment to the defense of Europe against Soviet domination; and third, the peaceful termination of the Cold War, which created the preconditions for a larger democratic European Union. </s> <s> These successes, however, give rise to a legitimate question: What next?NATO now confronts historically unprecedented risks to global security. </s> <s> The paradox of our time is that the world, increasingly connected and economically interdependent, is experiencing intensifying popular unrest. </s> <s> Yet there is no effective global security mechanism for coping with the growing threat of chaos stemming from humanity @-@ s recent political awakening. </s> <s> Additionally complicating is the fact that the dramatic rise of China and India and the quick recovery of Japan within the last 50 years have signaled that the global center of political and economic gravity is shifting away from the North Atlantic toward Asia and the Pacific. </s> <s> This dispersal of global power and the expanding mass unrest make for a combustible mixture. </s> <s> In this dangerous setting, the first order of business for NATO members is to define and pursue together a politically acceptable outcome to its <unk>of region military engagement in Afghanistan. </s> <s> This must be pursued on a genuinely shared military and economic basis, without caveats regarding military participation or evasions regarding financial assistance for Afghanistan and Pakistan. </s> <s> Such a resolution of NATO @-@ s first campaign based on Article 5 is necessary to sustain alliance credibility. </s> <s> However, the fact is that the qualified wording of Article 5 allows each country to do as much or as little as it thinks appropriate in response to an attack on a fellow NATO member, and NATO @-@ s reliance upon consensus for decision<unk> enables even just one or two members in effect to veto any response at all @-@ a problem made more acute by the expansion of the alliance to 28 members and the vulnerability of some members to foreign inducements. </s> <s> Hence, some thought should be given to formulating a more operational definition of @-@ consensus @-@ when it is shared by an overwhelming majority but not by everyone. </s> <s> The alliance also needs to define for itself a geopolitically relevant long-term strategic goal for its relationship with the Russian Federation. </s> <s> Russia is not an enemy, but it still views NATO with hostility. </s> <s> Hence, two strategic objectives should define NATO @-@ s goal: to consolidate security in Europe by drawing Russia into a closer association with the Euro-Atlantic community, and to engage Russia in a wider web of global security that indirectly facilitates the fading of Russia @-@ s lingering imperial ambitions. </s> <s> A good first step might be an agreement on security cooperation between NATO and the <unk>created Collective Security Treaty Organization, which consists of Armenia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russia, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan. </s> <s> In return for this concession @-@ which Moscow has long sought @-@ such an arrangement should be made conditional on provisions that confirm the right of current nonmembers to seek membership of their own choice in either NATO or the CSTO. </s> <s> Better relations between NATO and Russia could also facilitate a cooperative outreach toward the rising Asian powers, which should be drawn into joint security undertakings. </s> <s> Such gradually expanding cooperation could lead, in turn, to a joint NATO-Shanghai Cooperation Organization council, thereby indirectly engaging China in cooperation with NATO, clearly a desirable goal. </s> <s> Indeed, given the changing distribution of global power, NATO should soon consider more direct formal links with several leading East Asian powers @-@ especially China and Japan @-@ as well as with India. </s> <s> But to remain relevant, NATO cannot @-@ as some have urged @-@ simply expand itself into a global alliance or transform itself into a global alliance of democracies. </s> <s> A global NATO would dilute the centrality of the U. S<unk>European connection, and none of the rising powers would be likely to accept membership in a globally expanded NATO. </s> <s> Furthermore, an ideologically defined global alliance of democracies would face serious difficulties in determining whom to exclude and in striking a reasonable balance between its doctrinal and strategic purposes. </s> <s> NATO, however, has the experience, the institutions and the means to become the hub of a globe-spanning web of various regional cooperative-security undertakings among states with the growing power to act. </s> <s> In pursuing that strategic mission, NATO would not only be preserving <unk>Atlantic political unity; it would also be responding to the 21st century @-@ s increasingly urgent security agenda. </s> <s> Some in Russia S<unk>Russian relations. </s> <s> Nor are the technical obstacles trivial. </s> <s> For both practical and political reasons a fully integrated system with joint command and control may be a reach too far. </s> <s> Even separate but coordinated systems, the model experts think more likely, pose formidable challenges. </s> <s> But, significant as these hurdles are, the more fundamental point lies elsewhere. </s> <s> Political will, not technical obstacles, will determine whether missile defense becomes a pillar of a more inclusive and better-defended Euro-Atlantic community, or persists, even grows, as a source of tension and discord within what national leaders in their moment of hope at the Cold War @-@ s close spoke of as a @-@ Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals whole and free for the first time in 300 years. </s> <s> @-@ The necessary political will, however, will almost certainly not emerge where it must @-@ among all three parties, North America, Europe and Russia @-@ unless the process, the system and its implementation are of, by and for all three. </s> <s> It will not come if a <unk>defense system is essentially the creation of a single country with invited participation, or the work of two countries, or the project of an alliance. </s> <s> From the start, Europe, North America and Russia should assess jointly the common threat, and then undertake as equal parties to design from the ground up a common architecture to deal with the threat. </s> <s> Elements of the Obama administration @-@ s new U. Op-Ed Contributor By Mikhail GorbachevA remarkable sequence of events in April has turned the spotlight on the subject of nuclear disarmament and global security. </s> <s> I am referring to the signing by Presidents Obama and Medvedev of the New START treaty, the presentation of the Obama administration @-@ s nuclear doctrine and the nuclear security summit meeting in Washington attended by leaders of several dozen countries. </s> <s> The ice has broken. </s> <s> The situation today is dramatically different from just two years ago. </s> <s> But has it changed enough to say that the process now under way is irreversible? </s> <s> Let @-@ s first look at the New START treaty. </s> <s> It has been deemed irrelevant and the reductions it calls for described as @-@ creative accounting. </s> <s> @-@ Though the cuts are indeed modest compared to those made under the treaty the first President Bush and I signed in 1991, the treaty is a major breakthrough. </s> <s> First, it resumes the process initiated in the second half of the 1980s, which made it possible to rid the world of thousands of nuclear warheads and hundreds of launchers. </s> <s> Second, the strategic arsenals of the United States and Russia have once again been placed under a regime of mutual verification and inspections. </s> <s> Third, the United States and Russia have demonstrated that they can solve the most complex problems of mutual security, which offers hope that they will work together more successfully to address global and regional issues. </s> <s> Finally, and perhaps most importantly, with the New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty the two biggest nuclear powers say to the world that they are serious about their Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty obligation to move toward eliminating nuclear weapons. </s> <s> By reviving the goal of a world free of nuclear weapons, the treaty is a powerful tool for political pressure on those countries, particularly Iran and North Korea, whose nuclear programs have caused legitimate concern within the international community. </s> <s> It also reminds other nuclear weapon powers that they, too, must join in the process of nuclear disarmament. </s> <s> I have often been asked, in Russia and elsewhere, whether the process of nuclear disarmament could be scuttled by a build-up in the arsenals of other countries @-@ for example China, Pakistan and India. </s> <s> This is a legitimate question. </s> <s> The least that the other members of the @-@ nuclear club @-@ must do now is freeze their arsenals. </s> <s> Further progress along the path of disarmament and nonproliferation would be facilitated by a statement from nuclear powers saying that the sole purpose of nuclear weapons is to prevent their use. </s> <s> Unfortunately, the new U. S. nuclear doctrine does not go that far. </s> <s> Nevertheless, this document, as well as Russia @-@ s military doctrine, signals a tendency toward reduced reliance on nuclear weapons. </s> <s> The new U. S. doctrine emphasizes that Russia is no longer an adversary. </s> <s> It declares the Obama administration @-@ s intent to secure ratification of the treaty banning all nuclear testing and states that the United States will not develop new nuclear weapons. </s> <s> The Obama administration has proposed bilateral dialogues on strategic stability with Russia and China. </s> <s> Such a dialogue must include missile defense issues. </s> <s> After all, the <unk> of strategic offensive arms and missile defense is recognized in the New START. </s> <s> The dialogue on strategic stability is certainly in Russia @-@ s interest. </s> <s> To conduct it with confidence, we in Russia need a serious debate on the problem of missile defense, involving experts, members of Parliament and the military. </s> <s> What kind of missile defense does Russia need? </s> <s> Should it be linked with the U. S. missile defense system? </s> <s> These are political rather than @-@ agency @-@ issues. </s> <s> Decisions on such issues will be with us for decades to come. </s> <s> Yet, the proposed dialogue should not be limited to strategic weapons. </s> <s> More general problems must also be addressed if we are to build a relationship of partnership and trust. </s> <s> <unk> is the problem of military superiority. </s> <s> The U. S. national security strategy, adopted in 2002 and still in effect, clearly proclaims the need for U. S. global military superiority. </s> <s> This principle has in effect become an integral part of America @-@ s creed. </s> <s> It finds specific expression in the vast arsenals of conventional weapons, the colossal defense budget and the plans for weaponizing outer space. </s> <s> The proposed strategic dialogue must include all these issues. </s> <s> Reaching mutual understanding will take a sense of realism and long-term vision. </s> <s> NATO is now discussing a new @-@ strategic concept, @-@ and for the first time it is consulting with Russia. </s> <s> I welcome this. </s> <s> Does it mean that NATO is ready to renounce the claim to include the entire world in its @-@ zone of responsibility @-@ and instead work together with others within multilateral institutions vested with real authority and powers? </s> <s> The recent opinion essay by George Shultz and William Perry @-@ <unk> April 12 @-@ seems to suggest that influential Americans are now seriously considering such issues. </s> <s> I am sure that Russia is ready to engage in such a discussion, and not Russia alone. </s> <s> For whether we like it or not, the world today is multipolar. </s> <s> There has been much disingenuous talk that @-@ multipolar structures are inherently unstable, @-@ citing examples of Europe in the 19th and early 20th centuries and blaming <unk> for conflicts and wars, including world wars. </s> <s> Such talk is pointless, because miltipolarity is now a reality. </s> <s> We have seen in recent months that power centers like China, Russia and the European Union have responded to the global financial crisis responsibly. </s> <s> While defending their own interests they have taken into account the interests of other players and of the world community as a whole. </s> <s> This is <unk> in action, helping to mitigate the crisis and move toward addressing longer-term measures. </s> <s> But it @-@ s only a beginning. </s> <s> The Middle East peace process is in a deep crisis. </s> <s> The world is still paying for the mistakes of U. S. strategy in Iraq and Afghanistan. </s> <s> Efforts to agree on a global climate policy are stalled. </s> <s> The mechanisms for fighting poverty and backwardness are dysfunctional. </s> <s> In the final analysis, it all comes down to the lack of political will and failure of leadership. </s> <s> We need collective leadership. </s> <s> We have recently seen examples of what it can achieve. </s> <s> But what remains to be done is much more than what has been done. </s> <s> Too much time was wasted after the end of the Cold War. </s> <s> The legacy of mutual suspicion, narrow self-interest and domination is still very much with us. </s> <s> The struggle between this legacy and new thinking will define international politics in the 21st century. </s> <s> I. Op-Ed ContributorBy Linas LinkeviciusThis is the first time Lithuania is participating in a drafting of NATO @-@ s strategic concept, the first to be adopted since the enlargement of the alliance. </s> <s> Naturally we can expect an influx of ideas from the new allies. </s> <s> The strategic concept will have to explain to our societies what NATO stands for in the 21st century. </s> <s> Allies approach this task from two different perspectives. </s> <s> On the one hand they have to convince their publics that NATO is not a useless relic of the Cold War. </s> <s> On the other hand @-@ and strove for NATO membership. </s> <s> We needed to secure our regained freedom and independence. </s> <s> I have no doubt that the principle of @-@ reassurance @-@ will be duly reflected in the document. </s> <s> As NATO prepares to respond to new challenges @-@ <unk> defense, energy security, terrorism, piracy, etc. </s> <s> @-@ it is imperative that this not be done at the expense of its core principle. </s> <s> Reassurance is usually portrayed as a visible gesture to someone who feels threatened. </s> <s> In my understanding, reassurance within NATO means, first of all, confidence and commitment to one another among all the allies. </s> <s> I believe that reassurance is related not only to a particular concrete threat or ally, but rather to the political will and readiness to fulfill the basic task of the alliance @-@ collective defense. </s> <s> Reassurance is about getting our troops ready and <unk>. </s> <s> Only thus will we reassure one another and those who are concerned on the outside that the alliance can face modern challenges, and will not be transformed into a @-@ coalition of the willing. </s> <s> @-@ NATO is a defensive alliance, and does not consider any country to be its enemy. </s> <s> But there should be no doubts regarding NATO @-@ s resolve and capability to respond efficiently if the security of any member is threatened. </s> <s> Let me touch upon another aspect of reassurance: From time to time it is presented in connection with a stronger engagement @-@ a reset @-@ with Russia. </s> <s> I fail to see how relations with Russia should in any way be conditioned by NATO @-@ s reassurance policy. </s> <s> It is a false connection, whether it is presented positively @-@ that reassurance would encourage historically sensitive allies to have better relations with Russia @-@ or negatively @-@ as argued by Ambassador Wolfgang Ischinger and Admiral <unk> Weisser in the International Herald Tribune @-@ @-@ that engagement with Russia cannot be reconciled with military reassurance, which in the view of its proponents means defense planning against Russia. </s> <s> Reassurance should not be a factor in NATO-Russia relations. </s> <s> Reassurance policy is a practical implementation of collective defense. </s> <s> It is not directed at any one country, but against any threat that can be reasonably anticipated. </s> <s> As NATO is planning its defenses, so is Russia, and this should not in any way preclude cooperation or building confidence and transparency in our relations. </s> <s> Any obstacles to such cooperation are not military, but political. </s> <s> The desire of the U. S. administration @-@ and all of us @-@ to review, refresh and to some extent put our relations with Russia on a constructive, rational track is quite understandable. </s> <s> We need true engagement with Russia for strategic stability in Europe. </s> <s> We need Russia to fix the conventional arms control regime, we need it for the global war against terrorism, the fight against nuclear proliferation, and many other new security threats. </s> <s> But we must also be aware that on the other side, NATO is portrayed in Russia @-@ s security strategy not as a strategic friend and not even as a partner, but as a danger. </s> <s> So we need to ask ourselves: Do we really know what it means for NATO-Russia cooperation to succeed? </s> <s> Do we know what Russia is aiming for in this partnership? </s> <s> Does it correspond to our understanding of what it means? </s> <s> Do we really share the same values? </s> <s> We are well aware of Russia @-@ s concerns regarding NATO @-@ encirclement. </s> <s> @-@ And there are no fundamental differences within NATO in assessing the state of affairs inside Russia; the discussions, however, are on the tactical level, about how to move ahead. </s> <s> One approach asks what NATO can do to encourage change in Russia. </s> <s> Those who advocate this approach are reluctant to raise divisive issues in order to not undermine the process. </s> <s> I would say that under this approach, we are pushing not only the @-@ reset @-@ button, but also @-@ delete @-@ @-@ <unk> memory, commitments, obligations. </s> <s> Another approach is based on a belief that common interests should not trump values. </s> <s> Relations with Russia suffered as a consequence of its actions and policies, first of all in Georgia. </s> <s> This approach maintains that it is impossible to make progress toward healthy relations if Russia does not do its part in respecting existing treaties, political commitments and institutions. </s> <s> In a way, these two approaches were reconciled in the NATO policy agreed on in 2009; NATO will cooperate with Russia wherever possible, but will not shy away from raising issues on which we disagree. </s> <s> I am optimistic that relations can improve as Russia moves along on the path of modernization. </s> <s> Russia is not condemned to authoritarian rule. </s> <s> The best way to encourage democratic transformation is with open and principled positions. </s> <s> Once there is real progress in solving stalled security issues and bridging differences, NATO-Russia relations will improve substantially. </s> <s> And I can assure you that Lithuania will be the first to embrace this change, notwithstanding any historical sensitivity we have. </s> <s> By Peter Baker and Ellen BarryWASHINGTON @-@ The United States and Russia have broken a logjam in arms control negotiations and expect to sign a treaty next month to slash their nuclear arsenals to the lowest levels in half a century, officials in both nations said Wednesday. </s> <s> After months of deadlock and delay, the two sides have agreed to lower the limit on deployed strategic warheads by more than one-quarter and launchers by half, the officials said. </s> <s> The treaty will impose a new inspection regime to replace one that lapsed in December, but will not restrict American plans for missile defense based in Europe. </s> <s> President Obama and President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia plan to talk Friday to complete the agreement, but officials said they were optimistic that the deal was nearly done. </s> <s> The two sides have begun preparing for a signing ceremony in Prague on April 8, timing it to mark the anniversary of Mr. Obama @-@ s speech in the Czech capital outlining his vision for eventually ridding the world of nuclear weapons. </s> <s> The new treaty represents perhaps the most concrete foreign policy achievement for Mr. Obama since he took office 14 months ago and the most significant result of his effort to @-@ reset @-@ the troubled relationship with Russia. </s> <s> The administration wants to use it to build momentum for an international nuclear summit meeting in Washington just days after the signing ceremony and a more ambitious round of arms cuts later in his term. </s> <s> @-@ This gives a boost @-@ to the administration @-@ s efforts to build better ties to Russia, said Steven Pifer, a top State Department official under President George W. well and this adds to the positive in the relationship. </s> <s> @-@ More broadly, the White House hopes the treaty will build on the president @-@ s victory in the fight to overhaul health care, demonstrating progress on both the international and domestic fronts after months of frustration over unmet goals. </s> <s> The new <unk>year pact would replace the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty of 1991, or Start, which expired in December, and further extend cuts negotiated in 2002 by Mr. Bush in the Treaty of Moscow. </s> <s> Under the new pact, according to people briefed on it in Washington and Moscow, within seven years each side would have to cut its deployed strategic warheads to <unk> from the 2,200 now allowed. </s> <s> Each side would cut the total number of launchers to 800 from 1,600 now permitted. </s> <s> The number of nuclear-armed missiles and heavy bombers would be capped at 700 each. </s> <s> Neither the White House nor the Kremlin formally announced the agreement on <s> Daryl G. <unk>, executive director of the Arms Control Association, called it @-@ the first truly post-cold-war nuclear arms reduction treaty. </s> <s> @-@ Richard Burt, a former chief Start negotiator who now heads a disarmament advocacy group called Global Zero, said that the two presidents @-@ took a major step toward achieving their goal of global zero. </s> <s> @-@ The breakthrough ended nearly a year of tumultuous negotiations that dragged on far longer than anticipated. </s> <s> The two sides quarreled over verifying compliance, sharing telemetry and limiting missile defense </s> <s> The two presidents cut through disagreements during a telephone call on March 13. </s> <s> The treaty will go for ratification to the legislatures in both countries, and the politics of Wess MitchellOn Friday, almost a year to the day after his April 2009 speech in Prague, President Barack Obama will return to the Czech capital to sign a renegotiated nuclear arms-control treaty with President Dmitry Medvedev of Russia. </s> <s> The symbolism of the location is significant. </s> <s> By choosing a former Soviet satellite, the Obama administration is sending an important message: Contrary to much speculation, U. S. cooperation with Russia under the @-@ reset @-@ will not come at the expense of close U. S. allies in Central Europe. </s> <s> Central Europeans are skeptical on this point @-@ they are like any people who over history have suffered trauma and betrayal. </s> <s> Wedged between geopolitical massifs, theirs is a history marred by the potent combination of unfortunate geography, strong neighbors and realpolitik. </s> <s> They underwent a traumatic experience under Nazism and communism, and they have learned to be wary when great-power twosomes convene. </s> <s> On the one occasion when the Central Europeans enjoyed Western patronage @-@ the period between the great wars @-@ they learned that democratic great powers are as capable of bartering away their interests as undemocratic ones. </s> <s> In the combination of the Russia @-@ reset @-@ and the reconsideration of Bush-era <unk>defense plans, many in the region perceived the early stirrings of something deeper and more menacing: U. S. retrenchment from the @-@ <unk> Between. </s> <s> @-@ The resulting calls for @-@ strategic reassurance @-@ reflect a profound geopolitical need that is one of the great challenges facing the Atlantic Alliance today. </s> <s> To its credit, the Obama administration has been responsive to this need. </s> <s> In recent months, American officials have worked visibly to bolster regional confidence through NATO contingency planning, Patriot missiles in Poland, military exercises in the Baltic and Black Seas, the creation of strategic consultative mechanisms and forward movement on the new missile defense architecture. </s> <s> The United States should continue to support NATO contingency planning as it builds on the special capacities of Central European partners that can be applied to shared challenges. </s> <s> But it @-@ s important to look beyond security collaboration to build a long-term U. S<unk>Central European relationship. </s> <s> Washington must not repeat the mistake of allowing relations with Central Europe to become disproportionately hinged on a particular initiative or program, tying the value of the partner to the price of the project and leaving the @-@ stock @-@ of the alliance to fluctuate according to the ups and downs of the political calendar. </s> <s> A healthy relationship is made of a broader array of shared and even indispensable interests. </s> <s> U. S. policymakers should seek opportunities for visible, non-military regional engagement. </s> <s> For example, in keeping with the Obama administration @-@ s new export-promotion strategy, U. S. officials should place greater emphasis on commercial diplomacy in Central Europe. </s> <s> A number of underexplored opportunities exist for U. S. business investment, particularly in the vital energy sector. </s> <s> An important lesson we have learned is the interdependence of commercial and strategic interests. </s> <s> Second, if current U. S. regional initiatives, military and non-military alike, are to achieve scope and staying power, they must be couched within a broader re-examination of Central Europe @-@ s place in U. S. policy toward Europe as a whole. </s> <s> It is in the U. S. interest to understand how further European integration can advance American goals. </s> <s> Young people in Central Europe are especially enthusiastic about opportunities in Europe, and as Polish-German reconciliation deepens, membership in the European Union will become more important. </s> <s> But relations with America will still provide reassurance and confidence. </s> <s> Viewed from a broader geopolitical perspective, there is no higher-yield strategic investment the United States can make in Europe today than to aid in the <unk> of bonds between the E. U. </s> <s> @-@ s core members and those on its exposed eastern shoulder. </s> <s> Though largely neglected in current U. S. policy discussions, relations between Germany and Poland @-@ the E. U. </s> <s> @-@ s largest old and new member states @-@ carry as much importance for the future of Europe as <unk> relations did in the 1950s. </s> <s> Now, as then, the United States has the potential to play the role of <unk> to deeper <unk> reconciliation. </s> <s> Just as American policymakers once encouraged Germany and France to seek <unk> oversight over a contentious resource @-@ coal and steel @-@ as a first step toward deeper Europe-wide policy coordination, U. S. policymakers might consider encouraging Germany and Poland to seek <unk> oversight over another contentious resource @-@ natural gas @-@ as a first step toward reinvigorated E. U. integration. </s> <s> The key is to see unrealized but achievable opportunities in current problems for deepening U. S<unk>Central European and U. S<unk>European ties over the long term. </s> <s> While working to free the region of the old ghosts of strategic insecurity, Washington should go further @-@ using the fresh energy and momentum of the Prague Treaty as a window of opportunity for making deeper and more durable investments. </s> <s> By starting this process now, the Obama administration can anchor U. S<unk>Central European relations in something more stable than local and <unk>Atlantic geopolitics. </s> <s> Doing that would help to inoculate some of America @-@ s vital regional alliances against future episodes of turbulence. </s> <s> I. H. T. Op-Ed ContributorBy Ian J. BrzezinskiWASHINGTON @-@ On Friday, President Obama will convene with NATO and E. U. leaders in Lisbon. </s> <s> These summit meetings take place as the <unk>Atlantic community is beleaguered by the war in Afghanistan, financial crises, and an increasing sense that the United States and Europe are drifting apart. </s> <s> If the president is to reinvigorate <unk>Atlantic solidarity and U. S. leadership, he will have to accomplish five interrelated objectives at these meetings. </s> <s> First, President Obama must demonstrate unambiguous determination to prevail in Afghanistan. </s> <s> What has been a year of increasing Western forces is instead regarded as a year of European withdrawals and media accounts of a U. S. president focused solely on bringing American troops home. </s> <s> Without a clear U. S. commitment to win, one cannot expect Europe to sustain or increase its contributions to this important mission. </s> <s> The president @-@ s emphasis on @-@ transition, @-@ intended to convey progress through the transfer of responsibility and burden to the Afghan government, does not convey a commitment to win. </s> <s> It is inescapably imbued with the odor of withdrawal, if not retreat. </s> <s> It reinforces the insurgency @-@ s confidence, and makes allies and partners question not only their sacrifices of blood and treasure, but also the value of NATO and U. S. leadership. </s> <s> A forcefully articulated resolve to defeat the Taliban is the needed complement to the West @-@ s long-term commitment to Afghan political and economic development. </s> <s> Second, the president must reaffirm Europe @-@ s centrality in U. S. global strategy. </s> <s> The drifting apart of the two continents has many causes, but they include the Obama administration @-@ s failure to present a <unk>Atlantic agenda that goes much beyond Afghanistan and its vaguely defined @-@ reset @-@ of relations with Russia. </s> <s> Europe has been left with the impression that America views it as increasingly irrelevant to U. S. interests in the world at large. </s> <s> Yet, Europe and America are each stronger global players when they act together. </s> <s> Globalization has increased the need to leverage jointly their respective political, economic and military capabilities. </s> <s> With regard to the last point, at Lisbon the president should announce a decision to keep U. S. military forces based in Europe at their current levels, approximately 80,000 soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines. </s> <s> His administration promised to issue plans for the U. S. military presence in Europe after the <unk> of NATO @-@ s new Strategic Concept. </s> <s> Some in Washington, particularly those eager to slash the U. S. defense budget, are calling for the withdrawal of some 30,000 American forces. </s> <s> Keeping the U. S. military presence at its already historically low level would preserve the foundation of the U. S<unk>European security relationship. </s> <s> These forces are highly effective, low-cost force multipliers. </s> <s> They facilitate the training, planning and relationships essential for U. S. and European forces to fight together effectively in Afghanistan and elsewhere. </s> <s> Such a decision would convey a powerful demonstration of U. S. commitment to the <unk>Atlantic community. </s> <s> Third, the president needs to re-establish the vision of a Europe whole, free and secure as a guiding priority for the <unk>Atlantic relationship. </s> <s> Few in Europe see the United States defining a clear path toward eventual Georgian and Ukrainian membership in NATO and the European Union. </s> <s> The abandonment of this vision has strategic consequences. </s> <s> It undercuts those in Georgia and Ukraine who see their future in Europe. </s> <s> It reinforces Kremlin aspirations for a sphere of influence, a dynamic that undercuts those in Russia who wish for a democratic future and a constructive Russian role in world affairs. </s> <s> As has been the case with Poland and other Central European states, the integration of Georgia and Ukraine into these institutions would contribute to the normalization of Russia @-@ s relations with its neighbors. </s> <s> This imperative has been a missing element of a truly effective Russia reset policy. </s> <s> Fourth, NATO leaders must mitigate exaggerated expectations about the new Strategic Concept. </s> <s> Previous strategic concepts have been developed with discretion and little fanfare. </s> <s> Earliest editions were classified. </s> <s> The alliance <unk>hyped the development of this document. </s> <s> Because it is a public statement requiring consensus by 28 member states, its language is unlikely to be sufficiently dramatic to generate greater public appreciation for NATO. </s> <s> Such appreciation has never been determined by diplomatic documents but by U. </s> <s> S, leadership and commitment and the alliance @-@ s actions. </s> <s> Fifth, President Obama must chart the alliance @-@ s way forward in an era of financial austerity. </s> <s> The financial crisis precipitated defense budget cuts across NATO. </s> <s> This era promises to be prolonged and could unleash divisive, competitive dynamics that undercut unity and military capability. </s> <s> Lisbon should provide a defense-capability roadmap that leverages austerity to drive long overdue strategic <unk>, innovation and collaboration. </s> <s> The absence of such a roadmap is sure to deny NATO the military capabilities that are the substance of truly viable Strategic Concept. </s> <s> The Lisbon meetings present an urgent and complex set of challenges. </s> <s> Op-Ed Contributor By Wolfgang Ischinger and <unk> WeisserA recent report by George Robertson, a former secretary general of NATO, and two <unk>authors, Franklin Miller and <unk> Schake, criticizes the German proposal to withdraw the remaining American nuclear weapons from German territory as damaging not only to Germany, but to the alliance as a whole. </s> <s> The authors argue that the proposal was driven more by populist sentiment than any long-term strategic goal. </s> <s> This observation is wrong and misleading. </s> <s> While the Robertson report is based on outdated perceptions, the arguments presented merit a substantive response. </s> <s> First, it would be a grave mistake for NATO and its members to cling to the Cold War perception of Russia as a potential aggressor and not as a strategic partner with whom we share interests. </s> <s> Security and stability in Europe are only possible with Russia.
